extent.value: in 5 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, and 2 oversize folders in shared housing.

abstract.value: Rose Schneiderman (1882-1972) was a Jewish labor organizer, socialist, suffragist, campaigner for protective legislation for women, and leader of the Women's Trade Union League(WTUL). Schneiderman played a leading role in the New York City garment workers upsurge of 1909-14 and was founder and president of International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union (ILGWU), Local 62, Dry Goods Workers. After losing her bid for the presidency of the New York WTUL, she became in 1914 a national organizer for the ILGWU but, dissatisfied with the place of women in the Union, returned to the WTUL in 1916, and became head of the NY WTUL in 1918, and later the national WTUL, holding both posts throughout the remainder of the WTUL's existence (through 1950). After World War I, her focus shifted to legislative reform (with the notable exception of her opposition to the Equal Rights Amendment), and she drew close to the Democratic party and established a friendship with Eleanor Roosevelt. Schneiderman served on the National Recovery Administration's labor advisory board in 1934, and as Secretary of the New York State Department of Labor 1933-44. Her autobiography, <title render="italic">All for One</title>, was published in 1967. This collection contains correspondence (leading feminists are represented), a set of letters from Pauline Newman, autobiographical typescripts, speeches, clippings, minutes, reports, and other documents representing Schneiderman's activity in WTUL, in public service, and in the women's suffrage movement.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Rose Schneiderman Papers; TAM 018; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Rose Schneiderman in 1962; an additional accession was donated in 1965 by George N. Taylor. The accession number associated with these gifts is 1962.010.

<chronlist><head><emph render="bold">Chronology</emph> </head><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">Apr 6, 1882</date><event>Born in Saven, Poland.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1890</date><event>Came with parents to United States; family settled in New York City's Lower East Side.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1892-1893</date><event>Spent a year in Jewish orphanages after father's death.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1895</date><event>Left public school after ninth grade to become a cash girl in a department store.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1898</date><event>Became sewing machine operator in a cap factory.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1903</date><event>Helped organize the women in her shop into a local of the capmakers' union, thus starting her labor career.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1905</date><event>A leader in citywide capmakers' strike; joined New York Women's Trade Union League.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">ca. 1906</date><event>Elected vice president of New York WTUL.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1908</date><event>Left factory work to become an organizer for the WTUL.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1909-1914</date><event>A leader in shirtwaist and other general strikes of NewYork garment workers.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">ca. 1909-1917</date><event>Active as campaigner for woman suffrage.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">Dec 1914</date><event>Resigned as WTUL vice president and organizer.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1915-1916</date><event>National organizer for International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1918-1949</date><event>President of New York WTUL.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1920</date><event>Farmer Labor party candidate for U.S. Senator.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1924</date><event>Campaigned for La Follette for president.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1924 ff</date><event>Growing friendship with Eleanor Roosevelt (a WTUL member) and Franklin D. Roosevelt drew her toward Democratic party.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1926-1950</date><event>President of National WTUL.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1933-1935</date><event>Member of Labor Advisory Board, National Recovery Administration.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1937-1944</date><event>Secretary of New York State Department of Labor.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">1967</date><event>Published her autobiography, <emph render="italic">All for One</emph>, written in collaboration with Lucy Goldthwaite.</event></chronitem><chronitem><date calendar="gregorian" era="ce">Aug 11, 1972</date><event>Died at Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, New York City.</event></chronitem></chronlist>

These letters dated 1910-1912 are from Rose Schneiderman's close friend Pauline Newman, International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union organizer and official. It was formerly closed at the time of microfilming and therefore was not filmed.

subject.value: Women labor union members -- United States.

corpname.value: Women's Trade Union League of America

dsc.value:
Series I: Correspondence. (Reel 7099/113: Frames 1-914)127604Scope and Contents note

: Except for a restricted group of letters from Pauline Newman and a few letters in the Special Topics series on Reel 2, this reel includes the entire correspondence portion of the Rose Schneiderman Papers. It consists of letters (plus occasional telegrams and postcards) written to Schneiderman, with carbon copies of some of her replies.

Subseries A: Correspondence 1909-1914 (Reel 7099/113: Frames 1-366)127618Scope and Contents note

Personal rather than official in nature, it includes some forty letters touching upon the affairs of the Women's Trade Union League, from such correspondents as Alice Bean, Josephine Casey, Mary Dreier, Stella Franklin, Alice Henry, Helen Marot, Agnes Nestor, and Leonora O'Reilly. Schneiderman's participation in the suffrage movement finds reflection in scattered letters from Alva E. Belmont, Harriot Stanton Blatch, Inez Milholland, Anna Howard Shaw, and Harriet Taylor Upton. Upton's letter of July 17, 1912, and one from M. A. Sherwood, July 15, testify warmly to Schneiderman's effectiveness in the Ohio suffrage campaign of that year. A few letters, especially those of Joseph E. Cohen, touch upon socialist matters. Other correspondents include the labor leaders John Dyche and Hugh Frayne and Florence Simms of the YWCA.

Correspondence1276221909-191011Correspondence127621191112Correspondence127620191213Correspondence1276191913-191414Subseries B: Correspondence 1915-1964. (Reel 7099/113: Frames 367-785)127607Scope and Contents note

Correspondence in the second group, 1915-1964, is more diffuse and has more of the character of personal memorabilia. With three exceptions, each year is represented by no more than half a dozen items; some years are skipped altogether. The exceptions are large clusters of letters and telegrams sent on three occasions: in 1937, at the time of Schneiderman's appointment as New York State Secretary of Labor; in 1943, in observance of the twenty fifth anniversary of her presidency of the New York Women's Trade Union League; and in 1949, when she retired from that post. Corrpspondents in this portion of the reel include Margaret Dreier Robins (see esoecially June 24, 1922, June 14, 1943, and Schneiderman's reply of July 7, 1943), Mary Dreier, Leonora O'Reilly, Elisabeth Christman (including several letters in 1950 describing the closing down of the National WTUL headquarters), Frances Perkins, the English labor leader Margaret Bondfield, Franklin D. Roosevelt (several letters during his governorship), and Eleanor Roosevelt. On trade union affairs, Schneiderman in a letter of Feb. 6, 1916 to Benjamin Schlesinger submits her resignation as an ILGWU organizer. (See also her letter to Abe Baroff, Dec 1, 1916, on Reel 2, frames 262-263.) A letter from Max Zaritsky, June 7, 1934, announces her election to the general executive board of her own union, the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers. Several letters in 1938-1939 concern the National Women's Committee for a Leon Blum Colony in Palestine, of which Schneiderman was chair.

Correspondence1276171915-191715Correspondence1276161918-192216Correspondence1276151924, 192617Correspondence1276141929-193218Correspondence1276131933-193619Correspondence1276121937110Correspondence1276111938-1941111Shared Tamiment 040Correspondence1276101943-1947112Correspondence1276091949-1950113Correspondence1276081951, 1956-1957, 1960114Subseries C: Correspondence, Undated. (Reel 7099/113: Frames 786-914)127605Scope and Contents note

The undated letters are arranged in a rough chronological sequence as suggested by the content. Included area few letters from WTUL figures, including Mary Dreier, Mabel Gillespie, and Melinda Scott. (Undated items for a particular year are included with the correspondence for that year, either before or after the dated items.)

Correspondence127606undated115Correspondence not Microfilmed: Letter from Louis Friedland, Educational Director, ILGWU, to Jacob Hillquit (2/14/1920); Letter from Olga Long (Finnish Women's Cooperative Home, "Dear Comrade," [1912?]3802161912, 1920115ASeries II: Special Topics. (Reel 7099/114, Part 1: Frames 1-782)127579Scope and Contents note

(Reel 2, Part 1: Frames 1-782)

Subseries A: Women's Trade Union League.127595Scope and Contents note

Women's Trade Union League (Reel 2, Part 1: Frames 1-186): The items are divided, somewhat haphazardly, into three groups: general material (frames 1-60), speeches and articles by Rose Schneiderman (frames 63-157), and miscellaneous (frames 158-186). Included in the first group are: typed copies of reports in the Chicago Union Labor Advocate of the founding meetings of the National WTUL in 1903 (by one of the participants, Ellen Lindstrom), of the national "convention" of 1907 (actually a small conference held during the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor), and of early meetings of the Chicago and Boston branches; a typed report by Rose Schneiderman of her work as organizer for the New York WTUL in 1908-1909; minutes of a meeting of the Law Enforcement Committee of the New York WTUL in 1913; and the script of the League's surprise party for Schneiderman in 1943. In the second group (speeches and articles), each ofthe first two speeches lacks page 1. In a speech or article at the end of the group Schneiderman looks back over the fifty-year history of the New York WTUL after its decision to disband.

Woman Suffrage (Reel 2, Part 1: Frames 187-233): Includes two speeches, presumably by Rose Schneiderman, given at a "suffrage school" in Washington, DC, in 1913.

First International Congress of Working Women (Reel 2, Part 1: Frames 234-243): Contains several documents relating to the WTUL's efforts to convene this Congress, held in Washington DC in October 1919.

First International Congress of Working Women127592191931Subseries D: International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union.127589Scope and Contents note

International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union (Reel 2, Part 1: Frames 244-279): Consists largely of minutes of the Waist Makers Conference in New York City, 1910-11, of which Schneiderman was secretary.

International Ladies' Garment Workers Union1275901910-191132Subseries E: New York State Department of Labor. Industrial Board. Committee on Sanitation and Comfort.127587Scope and Contents note

New York State Department of Labor. Industrial Board. Committee on Sanitation and Comfort (Reel 2, Part 1: Frames 280-450): Includes letters to Schneiderman and other members from the committee's head, Pauline Goldmark, together with reports, drafts of sanitary regulations, and related papers. (See also letters on Reel 1, frames 356 and 363.)

New York State Department of Labor. Industrial Board. Committee on Sanitation and Comfort1275881913-191433Subseries F: Labor Advisory Board, National Recovery Administration.127583Scope and Contents note

Labor Advisory Board, National Recovery Administration (Reel 2, Part 1: Frames 451-661): ALoosely organized, includes three Schneiderman speeches, some correspondence, various internal memoranda and minutes, and an unsigned typescript history of the board.

Miscellaneous Speeches and Broadcasts by Rose Schneiderman (Reel 2, Part 1: Frames 662-782): Contains typsecripts of speeches and radio broadcasts given from 1935-1947.

Existence and Location of Copies

Photocopies of contents of Box 5 exist in Box 6 located at the Tamiment Library and are available for researcher use.

Conditions Governing Access

Original materials are fragile. Researchers must use photocopies in box 6.
